During my visit my mini me traveled by train trough Hungary and Austria with huge delight.There is a space for kids to play with trains, and get there first contact with this wonderful mini universe, and also a shop for the less young and even for the collectors. The prices are quite fair for the miniatures. You can also have a nice coffee and a quick snack wile you visit, and the prices at the miniversum cafeteria are quite good.Is a time well spent, and if you have small kids they will love it. Only one thing to point out, there should be more information in English, anyway is not a show stopper for the visit.I loved it very much.

Tiny little museum, big story. The staff are very friendly. I wandered in here the first time looking for the English language used book store, but was so taken with the idea of the miniversum I came back. This is a kid friendly place that does a good job telling the difficult story of Eastern Europe
Mini..ature. Its nice to see the smaller version of Budapest and Vienna, with so much details. Good place for families, especially a lot of the visitors with children. Well worth a visit..

Really fun for adults and children. Took my grandchildren who loved it, but I did too! Hungary and Austria re-created in miniature, with interactive buttons to make parts move or light up... the best fun for a couple of hours.

Unsuspected. When we were planning our trip to Budapest, my partner and I put this exibition on our 'if we had time' list. So when we visited, it left us apsolutrly in awe. The tiny figures and the architecture is apsolutely amating and paired with tiny train it was apsolitely phenomenal.

Surprise visit!. Walking down the street and saw this exhibition. Was attracted to bit about life under communism but a bit put off by the fact that it appeared to be all model railways. However in the end we were enchanted by the whole thing and it would be a must for under 12's
Spectacular. On a recent visit we came accross this building. It is spectacular and well worth seeking out. It is every child's dream and is of interest to adults also

Cooooooooool. Definitely the best museum ever! :DI was so devastated and tired when i came across this museum! Tickets weren't so expensive so bf and me entered! I felt like kid again! It was sooooo cool playing with trains and people!It is cool to see that someone payed attention to every detail! I mean, people are 1/5 mm high and everything is according to their size! Some of them you can move with some remote controls given! And details! What more to tell that the lace is painted on the windows like curtains! Fruit in supermarkets, only few micrometers big!! If you have respect to this such of work, then this museum is a definitely must see!

Family fun. We visited Miniversum with our 10 year old twins and they really loved it, especially the interactive parts. The attention to detail is fantastic and will appeal to all ages. It is a good break from culture for children (and adults!) and we would definitely recommend it.

Fun little place . We were walking on the shopping street and passed by this place. We decided to go in. Small admission fee. It didn't take long to see everything ... an hour at most. You can see Budapest and Vienna in miniatures. Very detailed. I don't think all the lights, sounds, and movements worked for the miniatures. Nonetheless, it was fun for the kids.

Lots to find. We spent maybe an hour here and it was great for all ages. There are buttons to press and loads of hidden secrets - we managed to find Tarzan and a dinosaur in someone's back garden, but I'm sure there are more to find! The history and information screens were also really insteresting. Only downside - we wanted to stop in the cafe but there was no one around to serve us although we waited a while.
Well worth a visit.. In essence it's a large model railway. However, the attention to detail is spellbinding, with plenty of buttons to press to keep the young and young at Heart amused.
A must see for families. For any model train fans or families travelling with kids this is a must see. Very reasonable entry fee and the interactive displays keep the kids amused for quite a while.

What a little gem!. We found Miniverse in the hotel guide book. It was such a lot of fun. At first we thought that it seemed a bit expensive for a model railway but this was simply fabulous and the four of us were entranced and entertained for much longer than we had expected. The model making is of a really high standard and the dioramas are full of llittle everyday incidents and surprises. Oh, it's also a pretty good representation of bits of Budapest along with neighbouring areas and even a station in Vienna. The trains are fab - on your way out don't miss taking a look at the complex control systems that allow the staff to spot any mechanical errors and sort them out. Small it may be, missable it's not.

Fantastic for all ages!. this has to be the best model of the city, villages, countryside and trains I've ever seen. Fantastic for the kids as it's interactive and we all had a ball trying to work out what button operates what. They also liked recognising places we'd been too!

Crank the childish you up a notch. I went there with my girlfriend, both of us in our mid 30s and loved it a lot. Spent 2 hours there. You cannot compare it to the one in Germany, but these guys have put a lot of effort into the project and deserve to get a lot of support as well. I absolutely loved it, played with all the interactive buttons trying to figure out what they start or what actions they are linked to. Some buttons need to be fixed, as they haven't worked properly, but they got the action started in the end. If you are not into doing childish things, just have a look at the trains and engines which work and travel on the boards. The price is good (around 6 EUR/adult) for the time spent. If you are obsessed with details, you probably need to book some more hours in there.There is a nice cafeteria inside, where we got a free drink with the mini-cards we got from the hotel.
Lovely surprise. Popped in off street. Chatty girl welcomed us and we wandered around watching &listening to chuffy train's while enjoying the beautiful mini landscape.

Ok.... I think this was ~€5 entry and it was nice but really for kids as it only takes a very short time unless you've got some childlike wonder handy :) it's not somewhere I'd pay to go again although there was some interesting info provided about Hungarian history. I didn't try the cafe. Spent ~20 mins walking through

Miniature Fun. Came here with my fiancée after seeing a poster on the metro. Its a great use of and hour or two and worth the visit.A miniature replica of Budapest and other European cities. There are plenty of interactive buttons which set something moving or a sound going off or lights flashing, a big part of the fun is finding what each button does.The models are so detailed, a huge amount of effort must have gone into this place. There are so many model trains traversing these huge mini cities that there is a control room monitoring all the train lines.Kids and big kids will love this place, I did!

Exactly as it sounds. A must if you love trains.exquisite miniatures of the famous landmarks of Budapest, took about 90 minutes to walk through. There are interactive parts, which I considered more like a hunt for what moves. It is not always clear what the buttons do so you will often have to scour the scene to find a man chopping grass or something. Regardless, it was a really enjoyable experience and contained some of the history of the city as well which was very interesting and would not have found elsewhere. Appropriate price.

Meant for kids but had a ball. Mini town museum of Hungary. Suppose it is meant for kids but my wife and I ventured in and ended up having a ball. Got there between 6.30 and 7 pm when they switch of the main lights to bring mini town to life. Was great fun. Also lots of details with towns and running trains.

Please make the time to go here. We don't have kids on this trip with us, but we behaved like kids ourselves. The displays are fantastic and at 6pm they turned the lights off so that we could experience the mini towns with their own lights on as a night time scene. Well worth the small entrance fee
5 mins from the opera and not expensive. if you go to the opera then pass by minversum its small and nice wont take half an hr and very cheap and the staff are super nice

Fantastic. We stumbled upon Miniversum accidentally and made plans to go back there. We weren't disappointed.While model railways and miniature landscapes may not be everyone's cup of tea (their loss) - if you have even one gram of child-like wonder left in you, you will be delighted by the level of detail captured in every scene. To rush is to miss everything. Whether it's the stocked shelves in barely visible shops, rioting skinheads or paragliding adrenaline junkies in the alps, the depth of detail and life in the layouts is staggering. Visitors can observe the operators in the control room and workshop, and presumably ask questions (we didn't) There's also a coffee shop and children's play area on site. Highly recommended. Lose yourself for an hour!

World class miniatures. Excellent indoor version of Rotterdam's Madurodam and Brussel's Mini Europe. Great level of detail, lively miniature replica of Budapest, and other Hungarian and Austrian cities. We were lucky to catch the half hour night time, when main lights go off, and models turn into evening mode.

Minature masterpiece. Enthralling attraction with never ending detail to wonder at. It is brilliantly crafted and very well presented. Lots of buttons to press and the night scene when they turn off the lights is spectacular. Helps if you like model trains !

Great place to visit while in Budapest, with or without children. We visited the place early on a Saturday afternoon, we had the luck to arrive when it was still quite empty, it got fairly crowded later that afternoon. My girls loved the place, it is really well done with a lot of things to look at, and some interesting information for both children and adults. It's a great way to spend 2 hours if the weather isn't great...

Interesting place for kid and adult. This place is perfect for everybody including kids.During our visit to Hungary, for my 8 yrs old daughter, this place is the highlight of the trip.There basically we can see mini version of Hungary and Austria famous places.It is so interactive because there are so many buttons that anybody can press to activate certain movement/action in this mini world.If you have kid and you are in Budapest, I suggest to visit this place.Easily you can spend 1-2 hrs here.

Perfect for a rainy afternoon with kids. A very detailed miniature world down Andrassy utca. The world includes several areas of Hungary and surrounding countries. Lots of interactive buttons for lights and sounds, kids will love it. (And so will some adults that are still young at heart)

MORE THERE THAN MEETS THE EYE. Stopped here to kill time while waiting for the Opera House Concert.It is a delightful model train display.From the outside it simply looked like a storefront exhibit.We almost walked away until an employee showed us that there was a hallway to vastly larger display rooms. Hidden from view was a vast wonderland of scenery representing Germany and Austria. It included country villages,castles,churches and mountains.I was most impressed with an incredible scale model of the train station I had just arrived at; Keletti in Budpest.It was unbelievably real.Hero's square is also represented.This is a train buff's delight. I was pleased to see that they are considerate of their customers furnishing a clean available restroom. There is a small snack bar where parents can relax while the kids explore the whole layout. They don't take advantage of you either charging reasonable prices. Model train buffs have a lot to see: 600 villages, 5000 little people,1000 autos, and 100 trains. I like the fact that they accommodate tourists with a 19:00 closing on weekdays and 2100 on weekends- no locking up at 5 here.I thought 1900 HUF adult fare a little pricey but there is a family ticket that covers 2 adults and 3 children for under $20 US dollars and the rent on Andrassy ut is not cheap. I predict this newattraction will soon be number 1 in Budapest.Glad I didn't miss it.
miniversum a world of wonder in miniature. Stumbled across this wonderful place on our first night in Budapest, absolutely fantastic few hours.

Utterly charming. Miniversum is a wonderful little world of Hungarian, Austrian and German cityscapes and countryside. It's complete with running trains, interactive elements and incredible detail of tiny people going about their varied lives. It's an utterly fascinating and beguiling way to spend some time and kids would love it.

Fun! for kids and adults. Miniversum is a display of models of some Hungarian and Austrian cities, all connected by a vast network of railroads constantly roamed by multiple little trains. I was impressed by the impeccable details that show how much the creators of these models love their job! Small people attending to their business, protesters, Christmas deer on the roof, - these cities live their own lives, and you can take some part by pushing buttons. Fans of trains can buy postards with trains in the gift shop.This wonderful place made me want to get a railroad set for Christmas! I guess I got too carried away!By the way, keep your entry ticket - it gives discount for the Ferris Wheel on Deak Ferenc Ter.

Enjoyable with kids. I visited this place with my 9 year-old niece - she absolutely loved it! There are not only the constantly moving little trains, but also tiny people, mini versions of real landmark buildings. Boys and even girls are totally absorbed here!
Nice option for kids. Interesting details, nice small city. Our son very interested in miniversum especially trains. You can spend reasonable money and time.

Good thing to do at night, especially kids. Many things close at 4 or 5. This is good to do on a rainy day or at night. I usually whip through museums and things very fast. I would've done it here as well (like 20-30min) if they hadn't shut off the lights for 30min and lit up the display so I waited until the lights came in so I could take pics. It's hard to take pictures when dark but kind of fun. I'm not sure if they make it dark and turn on the lights when it is light outside, maybe it's just after dark. Costs 1900 Hungarian

Worth visiting!. Larger than I expected. Childrend really enjoyed it. There are many interesting details to investigate. There is also a playroom for smaller children. The tour takes about 60-90 minutes.

Fun little museum . This place was a cute little model museum, and a nice way to spend an hour or so in a lighthearted environment. While probably more targeted towards kids, if you like model cities, trains etc it is quite a good setup. There are various buttons to push that set off lights, motion and sounds. Some other reviewers have said that they are not working, but that isn't true. Rather, it's a bit of a 'where's Wally' where you have to look hard for the motion or lights - but they're definitely there!If you had kids this would be a great little stop.

A great little spot for an hour or so.... A fun, interactive miniature museum. Kept myself and my twelve year old daughter occupied for an hour or two. It's fun trying to figure out what the interactive controls move or light up. Although I'm not convinced every one of them was working! Really glad we went.

Amazing place for miniature lovers. Went in chance as we've stumbled upon it while walking on Andrassy Blvd - and it was an amazing experience. This was the first time I saw a miniature expo so I really enjoyed it.If you want a even better view of the miniature and attention to details you should sit on the benches and look thru the window - like this you can better appreciate the details and effort put into this.
Spectacular.. This is a new centre. Up to the minute electronic computer controls. It is a must for train and model railway enthusiasts.my wife found it interesting too!

simply amazing. For big and small, an amazing indoor activity. So much effort put in these detailed models. Even in the characters of people if you pay close attention. Some stops show the real picture that you can compare with. My child (5 y) and myself where so happy to have been here. Will go again ....

worth visiting for miniature lover!. we definitely enjoyed the detailed models in this museum. The miniatures,buildings, landscape and figures are soooooooooo detail and nice! feel free to interact with the miniatures and explore on some of the funny stories hidden within the models. stay and enjoy longer. we appreciate the hard work.

See Wee Bits of Hungary, Austria and Germany. The Miniversum is a refreshing stop along the wealthy Andrássy ut. In about an hour or less you can get a taste of various scenes of life along the Danube in 3 countries. There's interactive buttons to make sounds, flash lights, and start windmills or open an outhouse door. The creators evidently have a passion as well as a sense of humor - the Dinosaur in Austria and the man relieving himself on a military installment in Hungary were fun finds.

Much better exibitions in Europe. Found on the net (search for model train exhibition in Budapest). Easy to find, good web site description. Although recommended by the vendor to book advance (maybe just a good marketing tool), we were there Sunday noon, no crowd.Disappointed to my son (4ys old) and to me since the model layout is narrow due to the room provided limits and the exhibition lacks any logic how its sections continue from one room to the next one. No interactivity although kids can push some bottoms to switch on and off some lamps. More than half did not work by the way.As shown on the photos, many elements were a bit weird such as shape of the football stadium is trapeze due to the room shape where the model was laid down, a highway is cut off. There is a lake which is plastic painted into green. I have seen so many models where water was used for various purposes (lakes, waterfalls, fountains, etc).The price was 15 EUR for 2I will not return

Miniversum, Budapest. As a young boy, I wanted to be a train driver, back in the days of steam ;-) I recently saw this attraction on a well known video sharing website and was inspired to visit.Miniversum is located on Andrassy Street, not far from the centre of town and easy to get to by walking or by Metro Line 1. I think the cost of entry (HUF1900 for adults, HUF1300 under14's and family tickets available) was very reasonable. It is possible to book tickets through their website, and this seems to be aimed at making sure that there are not to many people there during peak times, which would reduce the experience. The three main layouts take you on a journey through parts of Hungary,Austria and Germany, and show many well known landmarks in each of these areas. The buildings are, as far as I am aware, all hand built, and clearly to a very high and detailed standard.There is an interactive element to the layouts where visitors can press colour coded buttons to activate motions, light or sound on the layout. Some did not appear to be working, but that really didn't take much away from the experience. There is a lot of small detail and humour built into the layout. Figures are seen sun bathing on a roof terrace, police attending an accident, tramps sleeping by the side of the street, and much more. The layouts are computer controlled and you can see the monitors and handling software in operation at the end of the layouts.A small cafe operates in the building, which is very reasonably priced, a good point considering that the attraction is in a very touristy area of the city.All in all, it was a good experience, and one that I would be happy to recommend to anyone who has an interest in trains or modelling.

Spot the famous landmarks. See how many famous landmarks of Budapest you can spot as you walk around.The exhibit covers 3 countries; Hungary, Austria and Germany and 4 or 5 cities from each country.You begin in Budapest and here there is Heroes Square, Andrássy út, Budapest Zoo, Nyugati railway station and many others before moving on to other cities.Well made and with a number of interactive options to keep kids (of all ages) amused and entertained.

A treat for enthusiasts. We visited this after looking through the window when we were walking around Budapest. It is a very detailed 00 and n-guage railway model of Hungary, Germany and Austria. It is an enthusiasts dream.
Unexpected surprise. Walking about the streets we discovered this special place where we could see the city miniaturized. Very cool!

lovely place with kids to go on rainy day.. As expected, family ticket makes it affordable. very nice and attention to detailed work. I was amused, didn't know, should I touch them, watch, or take a picture ;-)

Not a big scale enough and not enough of Hungary. Children under 12 will have lots of fun and any train enthusiasts too as trains are everywhere in the landscape. But ...1,900 HUF for the entrance fee is rather expensive when you spend much less than an hour here (no senior discount but discounts for the 2nd or 3rd visits). I extended as much as possible my visit by clicking on every interactive button (some of them not working) but I managed barely 40mn, my friend zapped in 10mn!It is cute and well done but really tiny (the scale), I thought the scale would be much larger but it is the smallest possible to have running trains. What I really regretted because I was going there for the cultural aspect of what to visit in Hungary is that they only featured north western Hungary: Pannonhalma, Sopron, etc. and then some Austria & Germany but I would have like to see more of Hungary.

Decent opportunity to spend your free time.. After wathcing videos about different miniatire worlds, we (a couple) were more than excited to visit one of them in real. The one, which is located right on Andrassy, combines Hungarian, Austrian and German cities on the territory of 300 square meters. It is not comparable to Hamburg's "Miniature Wunderland" (1,150 square meters) because of Miniversum's simplicity. Nevertheless, we still got a lot of excitement while visiting it.This place didn't look busy at the time of our arrival around 6pm, so we were able to watch miniatures in peace. All cities were connected with a complex system of railroads (even above your head) that made this place quite dynamic. Some of the trains was possible to control yourself with a use of provided spinning wheels. There were also buttons, which activated movements of some objects in the little world. However, it was challenging to find them because of so small and unrecognizable movements of the objects itself.What disappointed us is that this exibition supposed to have Budapest and Vienna. However, there were literarly 3-5 familiar buildings in these cities. The miniature, which is located outside of Miniversum to advertize it, was much more Budapest-like than miniatures displayed inside.Another disappointment was that besides trains, there were no other transport in motion. It looked quite simple in contrast to Hamburg's one, where cars, busses, ships and airplanes move.Anyway, it is great to have such a unique opportunity in Budapest to stare at everyday's objects shink in 100 times!
Impressive. A detailed model of Hungarian life with interactive items. Great concept and worth a visit. Inside so we were able to avoid the rain for an hour or so.

Great place. It is a great place! I went there with my boyfriend and we really enjoyed our visit! It's interesting for everyone, is very well organized and made:) we had a lot of fun finding the different effect and lights:) i recommend to everyone to go!! The team who works there are very friendly and helpful!

Interesting. This model world is amazing for children and adults alike, you can spend hours just trying every button as they have thousands of functions. Real fun and even more if you have visited those places!

Something you never expect in the middle of the town. Our guide brought us to walk around the area to kill about 40 min before we leave for the airport. My friend and I didn't want to do any shopping. So, we just walked around and found a promotional cart in front of this mini museum. Wondering what it's for, we looked inside and saw the admission cost. So, we went in to check in. We were surprised to see this amazing mini museum which perfect served our purpose.

Fantastic attraction. This place is great, the layout is enourmous and there's so much to see. The interactive elements are good fun, and there's something for everyone, if you're just looking at the layouts or if you're interested in how they work and are put together.A must see!

Great way to spend an hour. We visited this place yesterday, very interesting and fun. Great for kids or adults with an interest in an overview of Budapest or model making. The trains alone are excellent

Nice for Model Train Enthusiasts. This is perfect for anyone into model trains. It is very well done, and you can see the time and effort which must have been involved in putting this together. I enjoyed seeing it, but I wouldn't go again.
while a nice idea but not enough to see. idea behind is nice but they should put more details explanation for visitors like us to understand the history behind the places inside .

nice but not good value for money. Miniversum is a mini train show - it was fun and interesting, but more for children, rather than for adults. It's also very expensive for the value / amount of time you spend there. Ok for a rainy day and if you have children, but there are more interesting things in Budapest.

A mini museum for all. Lots and lots of tiny figures and building. A model of Budapest and other Hungarian towns on a mini scale. Maybe more interesting to local Hungarians who know the areas well, although just as interesting for tourists.
Fun not only for kids. Very nice place, liked all the moving trains and cars and really had fun. I think this can be even more exiting for kids :).
Being a Child again. You can be a little child again. Funny scenes, nice details on this train model heaven. Well worth it.

Mimiature world - in the heart of Budapest. It is easy to find Miniversum in a central location of Budapest - ground-floor 12, Andrássy street . This is a great H0 size world- but not only for model-railway fans, but for everyone.You can see the landcapes and cities of 3 countries composed into the frame of railways, the focus of course is on Hungary. You can see some great views of parts of Budapest, Sopron, Pannonhalma and Győr - and the POIs created in miniature versions are like the real ones- beautiful and detailed ones. There are also interactive parts implemented - you push a button and something starts to happen on the fields- we came with kids and their favourite activity was to find these hidden secrets.There is a small buffet,shop also available and if the kids wants to try themselves, they can also play with small remote controlled trains in the kids play area.If you come with kids - add one more hour to let them play here...This is a must to see attraction in the heart of Budapest

Excellent fun. As a group of adults we decided to visit here and see what it was like. The place itself was much bigger than we thought and covered areas of Hungary, Austria and Germany. It's amazing how much detail they've gone into and if you look closely you'll see amusing little things that they've put in. Spent a good couple of hours here and loved every minute of it. We all enjoyed the interactive parts as well even though the youngest is twenty five!

Fun time for two adults!. My husband and I had a great time at Miniversum! As others have noted, it is most fun to watch from the kids' eye level...and pack your patience if you're going to test all of the buttons. We couldn't spot all of the moving parts, and some of them take awhile to materialize.

Nice relaxing break from the heat. Great fun.. This is a model village with loads going on. We went on our last day in Budapest where we were just looking for a bit of a chill out and some air con. We enjoyed it much more than we thought we would. Each 'city' has a load of activity including bits to be controlled by the user. Bonus points for the ludicrously bad taste of being able to control a paramedic giving somebody chest compression CPR!

A fantastic family attraction, but room for improvement. Miniversum is a a brilliant family attraction; rooms and a large enclosed courtyard full of miniture models, railways and buildings. The attraction is well designed, has an incredible level of detail, and variety of models and locations to keep the kids excited and entertained throughout. Everything from Heros Square, villages, circus, lakes, historical castles, mountains, ski slopes, military and so much more. I didnt count, but there are miles of train tracks and trains constantlz moving around the scenes. There's a cafe with good snack food, and a play area where children can build their own railways.Recommendations:Adults, when looking at the minature scenes sit down on the wooden ledge so that you're at eye level with the layout. It's singificantly better than always viewing from above. Look out for the dinosaur!Improvement:every few feet they provide buttons which can be pressed by visitors. Some flash lights, some turn wind turbines, or switch on little fountains. There's no guidance as to what button does what. I'm assuming Miniversum thinks its a fun challenge trying to spot what button does what action. It's not. It gets really frustrating for kids and adults pressing a button and having no idea what it does. Either I'm bad at this game, or by estimates 30-40% of the buttons don't work. I wish they could be labelled.
Go there if you like model trains. It is worth a visit! Very nice models of Hungarian (and Austrian/German) cities and of course many railroads and trains.

It's supposed to be for kids?. Went in here because it was raining.....and 6 adults had a fun couple of hours.The detail is fantastic. It is semi -interactive and we had a lot of fun with this .
Highly recommended.

A fun little place. I think this miniature model of Budapest and its surrounding is very impressive and fun with the action buttons, especially after you have seen the big places and you can compare from your memory :)Reminds to the ones of us who had train toys how fun it was to be a child and compensates a bit for the ones who didn't have the opportunity to play with such things in their childhood.

Interesting, novel and fun place to visit.. Very detailed buildings and cities. Really liked the interactive features but sometimes you have to look very closely to see exactly what light / sound you are activating. Bigger than we expected so it felt like good value for money. Took about an hour to get round.

Stumbled upon this excellent family stop!. Walking home from dinner we saw the Miniversum and knew we had to go in. On the weekends it is open until 9pm, so we went in and were glad we did! Our son loved looking at all the cars, trains, trucks, and people. There were many rooms with different cities represented, and a great kids room at the end where the kids can get hands on time with train sets. We would have stayed much longer if it wasn't already after dinner!

European Rail Adventure. Very impressive model railway with realistic train operations. Watch the OBB Railjet as it travels from Budapest to Germany via Austria. See Heroes Square and the Castle in Budapest, very accurate models of both. Spot the Dinosaur lurking. My Wife and I were only going to spend a short time there, but ended staying for 2 hours. Staff are very friendly.

Not only for children :). To tell the truth, I was tired after an hour to see the miniature figures, but at all I enjoy it. We spend there 2 hours with children to see the miniversum - the all. Try the buttons ant look for the moves, lights, sounds... It was super for the children, but also interesting for adults, too.The playroom was closed for painting, but the personnel let the children to paint also - it was a nice idea.

Must-see for everyone. This place is absolutely brilliant! I was curious before visiting Miniversum and it met all of my expectations. I was happy to see the Hungarian landscape and city streets besides their Austrian and German counterparts. "Muki' (freight trams in Budapest), Ikarus buses of various transportation companies as well as the passengers pushing the Ikarus Ik260T trolley bus. :)There's also a small café as well as a children's corner. Lots of small, lovely details, functioning scenes and a friendly, helpful staff. The only thing I missed from the souvenir shop were the Miniversum's own refrigerator magnets.

This place is amazing. Visited it with my young children. Not sure who was more amazed looking at this model train universe, the children or myself. Apparently it took 30 people a year to build it. It shows. The details are very fine from clucking chicken to funeral on the hillside for a backdrop. All the while over 80 trains roam the tracks disappearing in tunnels just to reappear at some unexpected corner next. If you are into model trains, set aside a few hours for this one.

Who needs kids to enjoy this?. Don't be fooled. Almost all the families you see there will be using the kids as a smokescreen to cover their own fascination! The layouts were seriously lifelike, a result of the larger HO gauge. Too many model railways forsake reality because they cram too much in by using a tiny scale. Here the spacious building (an old palace) affords enough room to spread out. Geographically the scenery progressed from Hungary through Austria, and eventually into Germany, affording a good mix of rolling-stock.We took the "Behind the Scenes" tour which we found fascinating and would definitely recommend.
The wonder of Europe. I visit this place with my family on the way to the St.Stephan Cathedral and it was a wonderful place to visit. The staff were friendly and the overall place is wonderful

Absolutely Excellent. This place is absolutely brilliant! There are so many different locomotives and trains to see run around the fantastically detailed layouts. Every little detail is represented beautifully, right down to little dustbins on the street, and people sitting in the station. The whole place is just wonderful, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves trains, or for someone who is looking for a place to take their children to.

Fun for children and men of a certain age. Very well set out and rather enjoyable if you like trains, transportation and technical stuff ( I do ). It's is a beautiful building so look up. There a cafe, small shop and toilet and the access is good. I managed to press all the buttons

cool place especially with family and kids. I was there with my 5 year old son and we both loved it. Cool place and so central. Huge train table covering regions of 3 countries with lots of sights from Budapest as well.

Amazing fun for kids. I was with my two 10-year old kids. In summary:- wonderful attraction set in a beautiful building- unique, never seen such a thing before- great how accurate the copy of the real sights has been: you see it in Budapest in real size then you come in and it's just awesome to see the same in miniature size- must-see, brand new- packed with interactive action- easy entertainment, can learn interesting fun facts about Hungary- a lot of entertainment and fun- well worth its price for HUF 1900 (adults)- separate section for kids, easy to spend 2-3 hours for families
Nice place. Nice place. WE were with two boys and we and the children are very enjoyed. Not many people know where it placed. The place is family freindly.

Wonderful attraction set in a beautiful building. This is a wonderful attraction set in a beautiful building in the middle of the city. I had not been a fan of such models before but we went because the children wanted to see it. I must admit I did not regret that I came along. It is great how accurate the copy of the real sights was: you see it in Budapest in real size then you come in and it's just awesome to see the same in miniature size. They opened a few months ago so everything is brand new and at the same time still a secret tip, I am sure it will be a much bigger crowd in a year or two. It is packed with interactive action and therefore everyone can learn interesting fun facts about Hungary. To summarise: it is a lot of entertainment and very well worth its price, you can easily spend 2-3 hours with the family for a family ticket at a price of less than 20 €.

Mini the place, Maxi the fun! . We were a bit hesitate to go in at first since we were thinking it seems like a toy store for 5 year old. We were so glad that we did it! Very amazing miniature city models. It's hard to believe that anyone could make such exquisite things! It's eye opening for both adults and kids!

Amazing trraction in the heart of Budapest. We recently visisted Miniversum in Budapest.The whole atosmphere is amazing, family freindly, the exhibition itself is in a beautiful, top detailed old, but very nice building in the heart of Budapest. It is a real good deal for a model train fun, I would say must see thing, everything is brand new, heavy railway tarffic on the layouts, very nice details and proffesional work can be identified there everywehre. The layouts are worked out perfectly, very unique deatils, nicea and perfect details as you just can see the in the real world in Budapest. Further to that certain locations from Germany and Austria also can be found on the layouts Hope these guys will keep up this quality work and they will extend their exhibitions with new themes. Also worth mentioning that entrance fee is very reasonable €6,5 for an adult.

One of the best in Budapest. Me and my friend just walked by and saw the miniversum and immeditly we entered. This was really great! Well built and alot of trains driving all the time. They built some of the citys nicest buildings and had som information about it. One of the few things I will remember from this city is miniversum! :D Thanks for the visit!

A must see place at Andrássy boulvard. We really underestimated the size of this attraction, it is a crazy sized sand table. 2 hours was not really enough for catch all the details, we will be back for an other round for sure.It is highly recommended not only with children, if you are older you will find some extremely funny details:)

Excellent time at Miniversum. My sister and I went after walking past while visiting Budapest. We enjoyed it immensely, there was information about each city depicted and we enjoyed the interactive buttons. There were numerous trains going in all directions, lots of tunnels and towns. There was much more there than we originally thought. It took us about one hour to go from start to finish. Highly recommended.

Great with small children (3 years and up). I absolutely loved it! Pay attention to all small details, kids will love the "treasure hunt game" when you push the buttons and explore the what will happen. Please do not spoil it for them, let them discover! You can do the tour in one hour but if your kids are train enthusiastics you may spend here easily 2-3 hours - especially if you try the pencakes in the café too! :-)

FANTASTIC!. We just noticed this place as we were walking along Andrassy ut, and thought we would have a look inside (I am a devout train enthusiast). This is a truly magical experience for anyone interested in trains, travel or central Europe. The layout is such that it depicts different towns and cities from around Hungary, Austria and Germany with trains running around the display which are small-scale versions of real-life trains from each country. Lots of well-designed model buildings and streets in each town (I particularly liked the townscape of Eisenach) and you can actually feel the different atmospheres of each country as you move between each display (I have been on trains in each of these countries and the atmosphere created here is what is felt on each country's real rail network)! I was particularly impressed by the very accurate train station announcements at Wien Hauptbahnhof, having been at the actual station only a few days before. Very friendly and helpful staff. There is even a play area for kids where they can create their own model train consists and then run them on small electrically-controlled tracks. A must for all visitors to Budapest who are interested in this sort of thing! And very easy to get to too by Metro line 1 to Opera station.

Great for Model Train Enthusiasts and Others. A model train layout featuring sites in Budapest, Austria and Germany. A fun thing to visit, it is interactive and plenty of trains to watch move through the towns, cities and even the Alps. Great for model train lovers an of course kids. You can also take photos and videos.

Excellent and unique experience for adults and kids. We have visited Miniversum with our 6-year-old son today. We have arrived around 11am on Saturday and found only a few people (as time passed more and more people showed up). If we had known in advance that we are going we would have the opportunity to book time online - great service (!). The location of the place is excellent even for local people. It is downtown Budapest in a very nice surrounding, however parking can be challenging and expensive - yet you can get 25% discount if you visit Miniversum - make sure to check online before.The place is exciting. It worth every penny on have to pay. They have good package for families with one or more kids. The exhibition takes you from Budapest all the way to Germany through Austria with model trains. Several famous buildings, typical landscapes are built up. The builders made efforts to make it interactive as much as possible and according to discussion with the employees even more developments are planned. Not only the landscape and buildings are amazing but you find lots of joke and "easter eggs" on the board watching the people on the streets, the cars and the landscape. It is fun just to visit, but if you can afford and you have the time participate in the tour behind the scenes!!! It is around 40 minutes and even my young son enjoyed it!I am convinced we will visit the place again!!AND if you are visiting with young kids make sure to go back to the "playground". There are tracks to build with, there are trains the control and even houses you can build!Plan at least 2 hrs to visit but you can easily spend there more!!!!

Awesome place!. I just went to Miniversum and I can't wait to bring some more friends. It's a really fun place, there's all this ungarian and austrian train stations and the trains are actually moving, you can even entertain yourself pushing the buttons!There were many kids but a lot of adults as well. My friends and I had a blast! I definitely recommend it!

Excellent place. I visited Miniversum during a family trip to Budapest with my children (9 and 6 years). The first impression when I entered the Miniversum was "overpriced", but when I noticed that it is not just one hall but several halls full of exciting miniature worlds, we all fell in love with the place. It was interesting to press the buttons and see what will change. There were also nice funny extra things hidden in the miniature worlds, which rewarded a visitor who looks the details carefully. Miniversum's clean toilets are a good bonus during a city trip with family.

unique place, great adventure. When visiting Budapest I strongly recommend to go and see Miniversum. Great location, unique amusement and high quality. Great for kids and adults at the same time. This place is one of a kind - was cool to be there.

Beautifully designed and realised model railway exhibition. Miniversum is a superb idea: a realistic model railway museum with fantastically thought out scenes that captivate and enchant. A delight for children and adults alike, the smooth motion of the trains really brings the detail in the scenes to life, and the child-like wonder on visitors' faces shows the value of the experience. There's also a convenient café making it ideal as a lunchtime stop on a stroll down into town from Heroes Square. Highly recommended!

Great miniatures, family friendly place!. If you & your children love trains, you should go to Miniversum. You'll see many trains go across the city, in the tunnel, on the bridge... Your children can also play with trains & have some snacks there.

Place that full of brilliant stuff.. I was traveling budapest with my partner and read the information about the Miniversum on the map. It seem interested, so we decided to go there. It was really nice. Many cool stuff there. We both enjoyed it. I also had been to the one in Hamburg before. Both of them are same the theme, but i found each of them have their own unique thing in it. It was really fun to visit. I do hope the gifts shop can be more bigger and more choices from the souvernir. I do know that it just opened about a week ago when we were there. So that is fine. We would like to visit again next time when we are in Budapest.

What great fun for kids and adults!. Although only 7 days since it opened, we had a great experience. My 4 year old son and I both had an equally fun time enjoying this train utopia for over 2.5 hours. Although you can walk through the exhibit in 15 minutes, you are not doing it justice. You should stop and marvel at the amazingly intricate details and hidden secrets in this incredibly realistic recreations of various real places (at least one hour). Take a break in the café and then spend the real time allowing your child or you (I admit I participated), in building your own tracks and playing with real models.I am not a train aficionado, however my son and I spent over 1.5 hours playing with trains. One tip: read the brochure and learn the code for pressing buttons throughout the exhibit so that you can make things light up, move or make sound. Enjoy!
